acqinfo.p: The collection was given by Dr. Leyburn following his retirement in 1972.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Information
bioghist.p: Dr. Leyburn was Dean of the Faculty and Professor of Sociology at Washington and Lee University from 1947 to 1972.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: Born in Hedgesville, West Virginia, on January 17, 1902, James Graham Leyburn was highly appreciated by his students. He became a professor of sociology and Dean of the University at Washington and Lee in 1947 and held the post of Dean until 1956 continuing as Professor of Sociology until 1972. In the 1920s and 1930s Dr. Leyburn held professional positions at Hollins College, Princeton University, and Yale University. In 1943 he was engaged by the Office of the Lend-Lease Administration to participate in a mission in South Africa.

This collection contains many materials relating to the South African mission. Dr. Leyburn saved a number of newspaper articles concerning South Africa which are contained herein. Reports on various industries and other aspects of South Africa are included. Also within this collection are an assortment of Dr. Leyburn's speeches, some of which address South Africa. The remainder of the speeches concern the future of Washington and Lee.

Among the correspondence in this collection are letters concerning Yale, W & L, and South Africa. A number of reviews of Dr. Leyburn's book, The Haitian People,as well as Dr. Leyburn's own reviews of other books are included.

The more telling items of this collection are the numerous student comments that Dr. Leyburn preserved. A voluminous journal of his world travels provides for interesting reading as does the poetry written by John Alexander Graham.
Appended to this collection are three scrapbooks which provide a record of Dr. Leyburn's activities at W & L and afterward.

Leyburn's articles on Africa, "Native Farm Labor," "Disabilities of the Southern African Native," and "The White Man in New Africa."
Articles on education including "The Education of a Southerner" and "A Plan for an Ideal College."
Articles on Haiti and the manuscript that was later extended and became THE HAITIAN PEOPLE.
Entry written by Dr. Leyburn for FUNK AND WAGNALLS STANDARD REFERENCE ENCYCLOPEDIA entitled "Negroes in the U.S."
Numerous articles by Dr. Leyburn on religion.
Article: "The Scotch-Irish: An American Social Force," published by NEW SOCIETY in 1962.
Miscellaneous articles on culture including "Notes on American Culture."
Book reviews written by Leyburn between 1961-65 for THE ROANOKE TIMES.
Book reviews written by Leyburn between 1944 and 1972 that appeared in periodicals.
Dr. Leyburn's correspondence concerning the abolishment of subsidized athletics which occured at Washington & Lee in 1954.
Clippings from newspapers, the RING-TUM PHI and THE ALUMNI MAGAZINE that deal with the athletic question at W & L.
University rebuttals to the aforementioned clippings and the introduction of "The Leyburn Plan."
Material from Dr. Leyburn's tenure as President of the Gamma Chapter of Virginia from 1962 to 1964.
Information about life at Washington and Lee during the 1960s.
Honorary degree candidate correspondence during Dr. Leyburn's time as Dean of the Faculty.
Various W & L programs of events including the program of the inauguration of President Fred Cole in 1961.
Various issues of the student newspaper, THE RING-TUM PHI.
Student papers collected by Dr. Leyburn.
Correspondence pertaining to Dr. Leyburn's tenure as Editor of SHENANDOAH, the literary magazine published by W & L, in 1959.
Dr. Leyburn's diary of 1968.
Materials pertaining to Dr. Leyburn's book, THE SCOTCH IRISH.
Correspondence from Terence Hughes concerning the publication of THE SCOTCH IRISH.
Reviews of THE SCOTCH IRISH.
Materials dealing with a conference on plantations in Puerto Rico in 1957 and the duPont Conference of 1961. Both were attended by Dr. Leyburn.
Honors College material.
Material on the history of Lexington, Virginia.
Miscellaneous papers and the KING JAMES BIBLE.
Dr. Leyburn's class lectures for Anthropology 101 and Sociology 303.
Dr. Leyburn's class lectures on the Greek and Latin Classics of Comparative Literature 202.
Dr. Leyburn's class lectures for Greek and Latin Classics, Religion and Society and General Sociology.
Dr. Leyburn's class lectures on General Sociology, class rolls for 1949-1971, and an autographed copy of Ellen Douglas Leyburn's SATIRIC ALLEGORY: MIRROR OF MAN.
